sp.p: My three years spent in War, has now undone my peace forever .
Good; be patient, Sir
She is my Wife by Contract before Heaven, and all the Angels, Sir.
I do believe you; but where is the remedy now? you see She is gone: another has possession
there is the torment.

This day, being the first of your Return unluckily proves the first too of her fastening her Uncle (Sir) the Governor of Rauenna holding a good opinion of the Bridegroom as he is fair-spoken (Sir) and wondrous mild.
there goes the Devil, in a Sheepskin.
with all speed clapped it up suddenly: I cannot think, (sure) that the Maid over-loves him: though being Married perhaps (for her own Credit) now She intends performance of an honest duteous wife.

Sir: I have a world of Busyness; question nothing, You will but loose your Labour, it is not fit for any (hardly mine own secrecy) to know what I intend: I take my Leave (Sir) I find such strange Employments in myself that unless Death pity me, and lay me down I shall not sleep these seven yeeres: that is the least (Sir)

that Sorrow is dangerous can abide no Council it is like a wound past Cure; Wrongs done to Love strike the heart deeply: None can truly judge of it
but the poor sencible Sufferer, whom it racks with un-believed Pains, which Men in health, that enjoy Love, not possibly can Act; (nay not so much as think:) in troth I pity him; His Sighs drink life-Blood in, this time of Feasting; A Banquet towards too? Not yet hath Riot played-out her last Scene? At such Entertainments still Here is Marriage sweetly honoured, in gorged Stomachs, and over-flowing Cups.
Where is she (Sirra?)
not far off.
prithee where? go fetch her hither: I will rid him away straight: The King is now risen (Sir)
I am a joyful Man to hear it (Sir) it seems he has Drunk the less: though I think he that has the least, has certainly enough.

I have observed this fellow, all the feast-time he hath not pledged one Cup, but looked most wickedly upon good Malego , flies to the Black-Iack still and sticks to small drink like a Water-Rat O ; here She comes: alas the poor Whore weeps, it is not for Grace now, all the world must judge: It is for Spleen, and madness against this Marriage: I do but think how she could beat the Vicar now, scratch the Man horribly, that gave the woman, the woman worst of all, if she durst do it. Why how now (Mistress ) this weeping needs not; for though my Master Marry for his Reputation, He means to keep you too.
how Sir?

he doth , indeed. he swore it to me, last Night: are you so simple (and have been five years traded?) as to think one Woman would serve him? fie; not an Empress; why, He will be sick of the wife within ten Nights, or never trust my Judgment.
will he, thinkst thou?
will he?
I find thee still so comfortable beshrew my heart, if I knew how to miss thee: they talk of Gentlemen, Perfumers, and such things; give me the kindness of the Master's-Man in my distress, say I.
it is your great Love (forsooth) please you with-draw yourself to yond private Parlour, For Banqueting stuff (as Sucketts, Jellies, Syrups) I will bring in myself.
I will take them kindly. Sir)

She has your grand-strumpets Complement to a tittle: it is a fair Building: it had need; it has just at this time some one, and twenty In-mates: but half of them are young Merchants; they will depart shortly. (they take but Rooms for Summer, and away they, when it grows foul-weather) marry then Come the Tearmers and commonly they are well booted for all seasons. But peace: no more: the Guests are coming in
the Fates have blessed me; have I met you privately?
why Sir? why Almachildes?
not a kiss.
I will call aloud, in faith.
I will stop your mouth.
upon my love to reputation I will tell the Duchess once more,
it is the way to make her laugh a little.
She will not think that you dare use a Maid of Honour thus.
Amsterdam swallow thee for a Puritan and Geneua cast thee up again, like She that sunk at Charing-crosse, and rose again at Queen hith
Aye these are the holly fruits of the sweet Vine, Sir. ~~

Sweet Venery be with thee, and I at the tail of my wish: I am a little head-strong, and so are most of the Company: I will to the Witches: they say they have Charms, and Tricks to Make a wench fall backwards, and lead a man herself to a Country-house some Mile out of the Town, like a fire-drake: there be such whoreson kind Girls, and such bawdy witches, and I will try conclusions.
A Banquet yet? why surely (my Lord Governor , Bacchus could never boast of a day till now to spread his power, and make his Glory known.
Sir: you have done nobly; though in modesty you keep it from us, know we understand so much All this days Cost, it is your great Love bestows in honour of the Bride, your virtuous Niece.
In love to Goodness, and your presence (Madam) so understood, it is rightly
now will I have a strange health after all these
what is that (my Lord?)
a Health in a strange Cup; if it shall go round.
Your Grace need not doubt (Sir) having seen so many pledged already: this fair Company cannot shrink now for one: so end there.
It shall: for all ends here: here is a full period.
a Skull (my Lord?)
Call it a soldiers-cup (man) fie how you fright the Women? I have sworn it shall go round, excepting only you (Sir) for your late Sickness, and the Bride herself, whose Health it is.
marry I thank heaven for that.

Our Duchess , I know will pledge us , though the Cup
was once her Fathers head; which as a Trophy we will keep till death, in memory of that Conquest: He was the greatest foe, our Steel ever struck at , and he was bravely slain; then took we thee into our bosoms Love : thou madest the Peace for all thy Country: thou: that Beauty did we are dearer than a Father ?, are we not
Yes (Sir) by much.
and we shall find that straight
that is an ill Bride-Cup, for a Marriage-day I do not like the fate of it .
good my Lord the Duchess looks pale: Let her not pledge you there.
pale?
Sir, not I.
See how your Lordship Fails now; the Rose not fresher; nor the Sun at rising more comfortably pleasing
Sir, to you, the Lord of this Days honour.
all first moving from your grace (Madam) and the Dukes great Favour; Sister it must.
this is the worst Fright that could come, to a concealed great Belly: I am with Child, and this will bring it out, Or make me Come some seven weeks sooner than we Maidens reckon.

did ever cruel, barbarous Act, match this? twice hath his Surfeits brought my father's Memory thus spitefully, and scornfully to mine Eyes, and I will endure it no more: it is in my heart since: I will be revenged, as far as death can lead me.
Am I the last man then? I may deserve to be the first one day.
Sir, it has gone round now.
the round? an excellent way to train up Soldiers. where is Bride , and Bridegroom ?
at your happy service.

a Boy tonight at least: I charge you look to it
or I will renounce you for industrious Subjects.
your Grace speaks like a worthy, and tried Soldier.
And you will do well, for one that never tossed Pike (Sir)
here am I (Mother)

Take in this Brazen Dish full of dear Ware, thou shalt have all when I die; and that will be
even just at twelve o'clock at night, come three year
and may you not have one o'clock into the dozen (Mother?)
No .

Your Spirits are then more unconscionable than Bakers; you will have lived then (Mother) six-score year to the hundred: and methinks after six-score years, the Devil might give you a Cast: for he is a fruiterer too, and has been from the beginning; the first Apple that ever was eaten, came through his fingers: The Costor-mongers then, I hold to be the ancientest Trade, though some would have the Tailor pricked down before him.

go : and take heed you shed not by the way: the hour must have her Portion, it is dear Syrup, each Charmed Drop is able to Confound
a famely consisting of nineteen;
Marry here is Stuff indeed Dear Syrup call you it? a little thing would make me give you a Dram of it , in a Posset and Cut you three years shorter.
thou art now about some Villainy?

Not I (for-sooth) truly the Devil is in her I think. how one Villain smells out another straight: there is no knavery but is nosed like a Dog, and can smell out a Dogs-meaning (Mother) I pray give me leave to ramble abroad tonight , with the Night-Mare; for I have a great mind to over-lay a fat Parsons Daughter.
and who shall lie with me then?
the great Cat, for one night (Mother) it is but a Night make shift with him for once.

you are a kind Son: but it is the nature of you all, I see that: you had rather hunt after strange Women still than lie with your own Mothers: Get thee gone; Sweat thy six ounces out about the Vessel and thou shalt play at Mid-night: the Night-Mare shall call thee when it walks.
thanks most sweet Mother.

Urchins, Elves, Hags, Satires, Pans, fawns, Silence. Kit with the Candle stick; Tritons, Centaurs, Dwarves, Imps, the Spoorne, the Mare, the Man in the Oak: the Hell-wayne, the Fire-Drake, the Puckle. #A. Ab. Hur. Hus

Heaven knows with what Unwillingness, and hate I enter this damned place: But such extremes of wrongs in love, fight against religious knowledge. that were I led by this disease, to deaths as numberless as Creatures that must die I could not shun the way: I know what it is
to pity Mad-men now, they are wretched things that ever were created, if they be of woman's making, and her faithless Vows: I fear they are now a-kissing: what is o'Clock ? it is now but Supper-time, But Night will come; and all new-Married Couples, make short Suppers; Whatever thou art; I have no time to fear thee, my horrors are so strong, and great already. that thou seem'st nothing: Up and laze not hadst thou my Busyness, thou couldst never sit so
it would firk thee into Air, a thousand mile beyond thy Ointments; I would I were read so much in thy black power, and mine own griefs
I am in great need of help; Wilt give me any.
thy Boldness takes me bravely: We are all sworn to sweat for such a Spirit. See: I regard thee I rise, and bid thee welcome; ~~ What is thy wish now?
o my heart swells with it. I must take breath first

Is it to Confound some Enemy on the Seas? it may be done tonight . Stadlin is with-in, She raises all your sudden ruinous Storms that Ship-wrack Barks , and tears up growing Oaks, flies over Houses, and takes Anno domini
out of a Rich man's Chimney, (a sweet place for it ) he would be hanged, ere he would set his own years there, they must be Chambered, in a five-pound Picture, a green silk Curtain drawn before the Eyes of it
(his rotten diseased years ) Or dost thou Envy the fat prosperity of any Neighbour? I will call forth Hoppo , and her Incantation can straight destroy the young of all his Cattle: blast vine-yards, Orchards, Meadows; or in one night transport his Dung, Hay, Corn, by Reekes, whole Stacks, into thine own Ground.

this would come most richly now to many a Country Grazier: But my Envy lies not so low, as Cattle, Corn, or Vines
it will trouble your best powers to give me ease.

is it to Starve
up Generation? to strike a Barrenness in Man, or Woman?
ha?
ha? did you feel me there? I knew Your Grief
Can there be such things done ?
are these the Skins of Serpents? these of Snakes?
I see they are.

so sure into what House these are Conveyed, knit with these Charmed, and retentive Knots, Neither the Man begets, nor Woman Breeds; no, nor performs the least desires of wedlock, being then a mutual duty: I could give thee Chiroconita, Adincantida Archimadon, Marmaritin Calicia, Which I could sort to Villainous Barren Ends, but this leads the same way: More I could instance: as the same Needles thrust into their pillows that sews, and socks
up dead men in their Sheets: a privy Gristle of a Man that hangs, after Sunset: good, excellent: yet all is there (Sir)
You could not do a Man that special kindness to part them utterly now? Could you do that?

No: Time must do it : We cannot disjoin Wedlock : it is of Heavens fastening: well may we raise Jars, Jealousies, Strifes, and heart-burning disagreements, like a thick Skurff over life, as did our Master
upon that patient Miracle: but the Work itself
our power cannot disjoint.
I depart happy in what I have then, being constrained to this: and grant you (greater Powers,) that dispose men, that I may never need this Hag again.
I know he loves Me not: nor there is no hope of it , it is for the Love of Mischief I do this. and that we are sworn to; the first oath we take.
o Mother, Mother.
what is the News with thee now?

there is the bravest young Gentleman within, and the fineliest Drunk; I thought he would have fallen into the Vessel; he stumbled at a Pipkin of Childes Grease: reeled against Stadlin, overthrew her, and in the tumbling-Cast, struck
up old Puckles heels
hoy-day:

I was fain to throw the Cat
upon her to save her honesty: and all little enough: I cried out still I pray be
Covered: See where he comes now (Mother.)
Call you these Witches? they be Tumblers methinks, very flat Tumblers
it is Almachildes : fresh Blood stirs in Me the man that I have lusted to enjoy I have had him thrice in Incubus already
Is your name Gooddy-Hag?
it is anything : Call me the horridest, and unhallowedest things that Life, and Nature trembles at, for Thee I will be the same: Thou comest for a love-charm now?
why thou art a Witch I think.
thou shalt have choice of twenty, wet, or dry.
nay let us have dry ones.
if thou wilt use it by way of Cup, and Potion I will give thee a Remora shall be-witch her straight
a Remora? what is that?

a little Suck-stone
some call it a Stalamprey, a small Fish.
and must it be buttered?
the Bones of a green frog too; wondrous precious, the flesh consumed by Pize mires
Pize-mires ? give me a Chamber-pot.
you shall see him go nigh to be so unmannerly, he will make water before my Mother, anon.
if now you talk of Frogs, I have somewhat here, I come not empty pocketed from a Banquet. (I learned that of my Haberdashers Wife.) look Goody Witch , there is a Toad in March-pane for you.
o Sir, you have fitted me.
and here is a Spawn or two of the same Paddock-Brood too, for your Son.
I thank your worship Sir: how comes your handkercher so sweetly thus bewrayed, sure it is wett-Sucket, Sir
this was kindly done Sir, and you shall sup with Me to-night, for this
how? sup with thee? dost think I will eat fried Rats, and pickled Spiders?
No: I can Command Sir, the best Meat in the whole Province , for my friends, and reverently served in too.
how?
in good fashion

let me but see that, and I will sup with you
The Cat and Fiddle ? an excellent Ordinary
You had a Devil once, in a fox-skin?
O; I have him still: Come Walk with me Sir.
how apt, and ready is a Drunkard now to Reel to the Devil? well. I will even In, and see how he eats, and I will be hanged if I be not the fatter of the twain with laughing at him.

Good Sir, Whence springs this Sadness? trust me Sir. You look not like a Man was Married yesterday: there could come no ill Tidings since last night to cause that discontent: I was wont to know all before you had a Wife (Sir) You never found me without those parts of Manhood, (Trust, and Secrecy)
I will not tell thee this.
not your true Servant (Sir?)

True? you will all flout according to your Tallent
the best a man can keep of you: and a hell it is for Masters to pay Wages, to be laughed at give order that two Cocks be boiled to Jolly.
how? two Cocks boiled to Jolly?
fetch half an Ounce of Pearl.

this is a Cullis, for a Consumption: and I hope one Night has not brought you to need the Cook already, and some part of the Gold-smith: what two Trades in four and twenty hours, and less time? pray heaven the Surgeon , and the Apothecary
keep out, and then it is well. you had better fortune (as far as I see) with your Strumpet Sojourner
(your little four Nobles a week: I never knew you eat one Ponado all the time you have kept her, and is it in one night now, come up to two-Cock broth? I wonder at the alteration strangely.
good morrow Gasper.
your hearty wishes Mistress , and your sweet Dreams come upon You .
what is that Sir?
in a good Husband , that is my real meaning
saw you my Brother ~~ lately
yes.
I met him now as sad (me-thought) as Grief could make a man, know you the cause?
not I: I know nothing: but half an ounce of Pearl, and kitchen-busyness which I will see performed with all fidelity, I will break my trust in nothing: not in porridge, I

I have the hardest fortune I think of a hundred Gentlewomen; some can make merry with a friend seven year, and nothing seen; as perfect a Maid still (to the worlds knowledge) as she came from Rocking. but it was my luck, at the first hour (forsooth) to prove too fruitful: sure I am near my time. I am yet but a young Scholar, I may fail in my Account; but certainly I do not. These Bastards come upon poor venturing Gentle women ten to one faster than your Legitimate Children. If I had been married I will be hanged, if I had been with Child so soon now: When they are once Husbands, they will be whipped ere they take such pains, as a Friend will do ; To come by water to the Backdoor at Midnight, there stay perhaps an hour in all weathers, with a pair of Reeking Water-men, laden with Bottles of wine, Chewets, and Curran-Custards, I may Curse
those Eg-pies, they are meat that help forward too fast This hath been usual with me, night by night (honesty forgive me) when my Brother has been dreaming of no such Junkets, yet he hath fared the better for my sake, though he little think for what, nor must he ever. My Friend promised me to provide safely for me, and devise a Means to save my Credit here in the house. My Brother sure would kill me if he knew it; and powder
up my Friend, and all his kindred for an East Indian Voyage.
Alone Sister?
No : there is another with Me, though You see it not: Morrow (sweet Sister) how have you slept tonight ?
more than I thought I should: I have had good rest.
I am glad to hear it .
Sister, methinks you are too long alone, and loose much good time, sociable, and honest; I am for the Married life, I must praise that now.

I cannot blame you (Sister) to commend it You have happened well (no doubt) on a kind Husband , and that is not every Woman's fortune (Sister) You know if he were any but my Brother
my praises should not leave him yet so soon.
I must acknowledge (Sister) that my life is happily blessed with him, he is no Gamester, that ever I could find, or hear of yet; nor Mid-night Surfeiter: he does intend to leave Tobacco too.
why here is a Husband;

he saw it did offend me, and swore freely he would never take pleasure in a Toy again that should Displease me: some Knights
Wives in Town will have great hope, upon his reformation to bring their Husbands breathes into the old fashion, and make them kiss like Christians, not like Pagans,
I promise you (Sister) it will be a worthy work, to put down all these Pipers; it is great pity there should not be a Statute against them, as against Fiddlers.

these good Offices, if you had a Husband, you might exercise to the good of the Common-wealth, and do much profit: beside it is a Comfort to a Woman to have Children (Sister) a great Blessing certainly.
they will come fast enough.
not so fast neither, as they are still welcome to an honest woman.
how near she comes to me? I protest she grates my very skin.
were I conceived with Child beshrew my heart, I should be so proud of it:
that is natural: Pride is a kind of Swelling: and yet I have small cause to be proud of mine.
you are no good Companion for a Wife, get you a Husband; pre-thee (Sister) do, that I may ask your Council now and then it will mend your discourse much: You Maids know nothing
No : we are fools: but commonly we prove quicker Mothers, than you that have Husbands, (I am sure I shall else; I may speak for one)
I will not look upon her: I will pass by and make as though I see her not.
Why Sir, pray your opinion, by the way, with leave (Sir) I am counselling your Sister here, to Marry.
to Marry? soft: the Priest is not at leisure yet: some five year hence: would you fain Marry (Sister?)
I have no such hunger to it (Sir) for I think I have a good bit, that well may stay my Stomach. as well as any that broke-fast a Sinner.
though she seem tall of growth, she is short in years of some that seem much lower: how old Sister? not seventeen, for a yard of Lawn?
not yet Sir.
I told you so .
I would he had laid a Wager of Old Shirts rather, I shall have more need of them shortly: and yet a yard of Lawn will serve for a Christening-Cloth I have use for everything, as my case stands.
I care not if I try my Voice this Morning but I have got a Cold Sir, by your means,
I will strive to mend that fault.
I thank you Sir.

l.emph: then we say that Life is best.
then we only praise the wife
There is but one State more to try
which makes women Laugh, or Cry
the Middle is best, and that give me.

sp.p: there is thy reward.
I will not grumble (Sir) like some Musician; if more come, it is welcome.

such Tricks has made me do all that I have done, your kissing Married-folks, spoils all the Maids that ever live in the house with them: o here he comes with his Bags, and Bottles, he was born to lead poor water-men, and I.

go Fellows into the Larder, let the Bake-meats
be sorted by themselves .
why Sir?
look the Canary-Bottles, be well stopped, the three of Claret shall be drunk at dinner.

my good Sir; you are too plenteous of these Courtesies indeed you are; forbear them, I beseech ye, I know no merit in me, but poor Love and a true Friends well-wishing, that can cause this kindness in excess: in the State that I am I shall go near to kick this fellow shortly and send him down stayres, with his Bag, and Baggage, Why comes he now I am Married? there is the point. I pray forbear these things.

alas you know Sir, these idle Toys, which you call Courtesies, they cost me nothing but my Servants Travail. One Office must be kind (Sir) to another
you know the fashion: What, the Gentle-woman your Sister is sad methinks
I know no Cause she has
Nor shall you. by my good-will. What do you mean Sir, shall I stay here, to shame myself. and you? the Time may be toNight, for aught you know.
peace: there is means wrought, I tell thee.
Aye Sir, when?
how now? what is he.
o, this is the Man, Sir, I entertained this Morning, for my Service, please you to give your liking
yes: he is welcome, I like him not amiss: thou wouldst speak Busyness, Wouldst thou not?
yes; may it please you Sir, there is a Gentleman from the Northern parts, hath brought a Letter, as it seems in #haste.
from whom?

your bonny
Lady Mother, Sir.
you are kindly welcome, Sir: how doth she?
I left her heal very well Sir.

I pray send your Sister down with all speed to me
I hope it will prove much for her good, in the way of her Preferment; Fail me not, I desire you (Son) nor Let any Excuse of hers with-hold her; I have sent, (ready furnished) Horse and Man for her.
Now? have I thought upon You ?
peace, good Sir. you are worthy of a kindness another time.

her Will shall be obeyed: Sister , prepare yourself
you must down with all speed.
I know down I must; and good-speed send me.
it is our Mothers pleasure.
good Sir write back again, and certify her I am at my hearts wish here; I am with my Friends and can be but well, say:
You shall pardon me (Sister) I hold it no wise part, to Contradict her, nor would I council you to it .
it is so uncouth living in the Country, now I am used to the City that I shall never endure it.

perhaps forsooth it is not her meaning You shall live there long
I do not think but after a Month, or so you
will be sent
up again: that is my Conceit. however, let her have her Will.
Aye (good Sir) great reason it is she should
I am sorry (Sister) it is our hard fortune, thus to part so soon.
the Sorrow will be mine.

please you walk in (Sir) we
will have one Health into those Northern Parts though I be sick at heart.
Aye Sir, a deep one, Which you shall pledge too.
you shall pardon me: I have pledged one too deep already Sir.
peace; all is provided for: thy Wine is laid in Sugar, and Spice: the Place not ten Mile hence What cause have Maids now, to Complain of Men, when a farm-house can make all whole again?

It takes: has no Content: how well she bears it yet? hardly myself can find so much from her that am acquainted with the Cold Disease
O honesty is a rare Wealth in a Woman, it knows no want, at least will express none; (not in a Look) yet I am not thoroughly happy: his Ill, does me no good: well may it keep me from open rage, and Madness for a time, but I feel hearts-grief in the same place, still; What makes the greatest Torment amongst lost Souls? it is not so much the horror of their pains (though they be infinite) as the loss of Joys: It is that Deprivation, is the Mother of all the Groans in Hell: and here on Earth of all the red sighs in the hearts of Lovers; Still She is not mine, that can be no Man's else till I be nothing, if Religion have the same strength for Me, as it has for others holly Vows witness, that our Souls were married
Where are You (Sir,) Come pray give your Attendance. here is my Lord Governor Come.
where is our new Kindred? not Stirring yet I think?
yes, my good Lord: please you walk near?
Come Gentlemen , we will Enter.
I have done it upon a Breach; this is a less Venture.

What a mad toy, took me, to Sup with Witches? fie of all drunken humours, by this hand I could beat myself when I think of it; and the Rascals made me good Cheer too: and to my Understanding then eat some of every dish, and spoiled the rest. but coming to my Lodging, I remember I was as hungry as a tired Foot Post. What is this? O, it is the Charm her Hagship gave me, for my Duchess obstinate Woman; wound about a three-penny silk Ribbon, of three Colours, Necte tribus Nodis ternos Amoretta Colores.
Amoretta: why there is her Name indeed. Necte ~~ Amoretta ~~ again, two Bouts, Nodo et Veneris, dic Vincula Necte.
Nay if Veneris be one, I am sure there is no dead flesh in it. If I should undertake to Construe this now, I should make a fine piece of work of it for few young Gallants are given to good Construction of anything (hardly of their best friends wives Sisters, or Nieces:) Let me see what I can do now. Necte tribus Nodis: Nick of the Tribe of Noddies Ternos Colores , that makes Turned Colours,
Nodo et Veneris , Goes to his Venery like a Noddy, Dic vincula , with Dick the Vintners Boy Here were a sweet Charm now, if this were the Meaning of it
and very likely to over-come an honourable Gentlewoman. The whoreson old Helcat, would have given me the Brain of a Cat once, in my handkerch'er , I bad her make sauce with it with a vengeance: And a Little Bone in the hithermost part of a Wolf's Tail I bad her pick her Teeth with it , with a pestilence; Nay this is somewhat Cleanly yet, and hansom, a Coloured Ribbon? a fine gentle Charm , a Man may give it his Sister, his Brothers wife ordinarily: See; here she comes luckily.
Blessed Powers; What secret sin have I committed that still you send this punishment upon me?
it is but a gentle punishment: so take it.
why Sir, what mean you? will you ravish me,?
what in the Gallery? and the Sun peep in? there is fitter time, and place: it is in her Bosom now.
go: you are the rudest thing ever came at Court.
well: well: I hope you will tell me another tale ere you be two hours older: a rude thing? I will make you eat your word; I will make all split else.

nay: now I think of it better: I am too blame too there is not a sweeter Gentleman in Court: Nobly descended too, and Dances well beshrew my heart; I will take him, when there is time, he will be Catched up quickly: the Duchess says she has some Employment for him, and has sworn me to use my best Art in it : life of my Joys, there were good stuff: I will not trust her with him, I will call him back again: he must not keep out of my sight so long; I shall grow mad then

He lives not now to see tomorrow spent if this Means take effect, as there is no hardness in it. Last night he played his horrid Game again, Came to my Bed-side at the full of Midnight, and in his hand that fatal fearful Cup; Waked me; and forced me pledge him, to my trembling, and my dead father's scorn; that wounds my sight that his Remembrance should be raised in spite. But either his Confusion, or mine ends it; o Amoretta, hast thou Met him, yet speak Wench, hast done that for me?,
what (good Madam?)

destruction of my hopes; dost ask that now?
didst thou not swear to Me, out of thy hate to Almachildes , thou wouldst dissemble him a loving Entertainment, and a Meeting, where I should work my will?

good Madam pardon me: a loving Entertainment I do protest myself to give him, (with all speed I can too) but, as I am yet a Maid (a perfect one) as the old time was wont to afford, when there was few Tricks, and little Cunning stirring I can dissemble none that will serve your turn, he must have even a right one, and a plain one.
thou makest me doubt thy health: speak, art thou well?
o never better; if he would make #hast and come back quickly: he stays now too long
I am quite lost in this woman: What is that fell out of her Bosom now? some Love-token.
nay, I will say that for him: he is the uncivillest Gentleman: and every way desertless.
who is that now? she discommends so fast?
I could not love him ( Madam) of any man, in Court.
What is he now. ~~ prithee?
who should it be, but Almachildes , (Madam ?) I never hated man so deeply yet.
as Almachildes?
I am sick (good Madam) when I but hear him named.
how is this possible? but how thou saidst thou lovedest him; and didst raise him above all the Court, in praises.
how great people may speak their pleasure, Madam; but surely I should think the worse of my Tongue while I lived then.

No longer have I patience to forbear thee: He is a Gentleman deserves as much as ever Fortune yet, bestowed on Man: the Glory, and prime lustre of our Court; Nor can there any but ourself, be worthy of him; and take you notice of that now from Me, say you have Warning of it: if you did love him, you must not now.
Let your Grace never fear it
thy name is Amoretta , as Ours is, it has made me Love, and trust thee.
and my faithfulness has appeared well in the proof still. has it not (Madam?)
but if it fail now, it is nothing
then it shall not. I know he will not be long from fluttering about this place, now he has had a sight of me; and I will perform In all that I vowed (Madam) faithfully.
then am I blessed, both in Revenge, and Love and thou shalt taste the Sweetness

What Your Aims be I list not to enquire: All I desire is to preserve a Competent honesty both for mine own, and his use that shall have me (whose luck soere it be) o He is returned already I knew he would not fail.
it works by this time or the Devil is in it : I think: I will never trust Witch else nor sup with them this Twelve month.
I must sooth him now: and it is great pain to do it against ones stomach.
now Amoretta ?

Now you are wellcom Sir,
if you would come always thus.
o, am I so? is the case altered since?

if you would be rude, and know your times, it were somewhat: a great Comfort: alas: I could be as loving and as venturous as any Woman (we are all flesh and blood Man ) If you could play the Game out modestly and not be-tray your Hand: I must have care Sir, You know I have a Marriage-time, to Come, but look to the Main Chance, (that is Reputation ,) and then do what they list.

wilt hear my oath? By the sweet health of youth, I will be careful,
and never prate of it: nor like a Cunning Snarer make thy Clipped Name, the Bird, to Call in others
Well: yielding then to such Conditions, as my poor Bashfulness shall require from you , I shall yield shortly after.
I will consent to them and may thy sweet Humility be a Pattern for all proud women, living.
they are beholding to you
So , So : away with him: I love to get them , but not to keep them . Dost thou know the House?
No matter for the House, I know the Porch.

there is six pence more For that: away: keep close: My Tailor told me he sent away a Maid Servant
well ballast of all sides, within these Nine days: his wife never dreamed of it : gave the Drab, ten pound, and she never troubles Him: a Common fashion: He told me it was to rid away a Scape, and I have sent him this for it : I remember a friend of mine once served a prating Trades-man just on this fashion (to a hair in troth) it is a good ease to a Man; you can swell a Maid up
and rid her for ten pound: (there is the purse back again whatever becomes of your Money, or your Maid) this Comes of Bragging now: It is well for the Boy too he will get an excellent Trade by it : and one Sundays go like a Gentleman that has pawned his Rapier. He need not Care what Countryman his father was nor what his Mother was, when he was gotten
the Boy will do well certain: give him grace, to have a quick hand, and convey things cleanly, it will be his own another day: O; well said art almost furnished? there is such a Toil always to set a Woman to horse: a mighty trouble: The Letter came to Your Brothers hands I know on Thursday last by Noon; You were expected there yesterday night.
it makes the better, Sir.
We must take heed we ride through all the Puddles betwixt this, and that now; that your Safeguard there may be most probably dabbled.
alas, Sir, I never marked till now: I hate myself, how monstrous thin I look.
not monstrous neither: a little sharp in the Nose, like a Country Wood-cock.
fie: fie: how pale I am? I shall be-tray myself I would you would box me well, and handsomely to get me into Colour.

not I: pardon me: that let a Husband do, When he has married you
a friend at Court will never offer that: Come: how much Spice, and Sugar have you left now at this poor one Months Voyage?
sure not much Sir, I think some quarter of a pound of Sugar, and half an ounce of Spice.

here is no sweet Charge; and there was thirty pound: good weight, and true beside what my Man stole when it was a-weighing and that was three pound more; I will speak with least. the Rhenish wine is it all run out in Caudles too?
do you ask that (Sir) it is of a weeks departure. You see what it is now, to get Children, Sir.
your Mares are ready both, Sir.
Come; we will up then: Youth: give my Sister a straight Wand: there is two-pence.
I will give her a fine Whip , Sir.
No: No: No: though we have both deserved it.
here is a new one.
prithee talk to us of no Whips (good Boy) my heart aches when I see them: Let us away.

This You that was a Maid? how are you born to deceive Men? I had thought to have married you , I had been finely handled, had I not? I will say that man is wise ever hereafter that tries his wife beforehand : it is no marvel You should profess such Bashfulness, to Blind one, as if you durst not look a man in the face Your Modesty would blush so : Why do you not run, and tell the Duchess now? go ; you should tell all: Let her know this too: why here is the plague now: it is hard at first to win them : When they are gotten there is no way to be rid of them : they stick to a Man like Bird lime: my Oath is Out: will you release me, I will release myself else.
nay sure I will bring you to your Sight again: say, thou must either die, or kill the Duke: for one of them thou must do.
how, (good Madam?)

Thou hast thy Choice, and to that purpose, Sir I have given thee knowledge now of what thou hast, and what thou must do , to be worthy of it . You must not think to. Come by such a Fortune without Desert, that were unreasonable. He that is not born to honour, must not look to have it Come with ease to him. he must win it : Take but into thine Actions, Wit, and Courage that is all we ask of thee: But if through weakness of a poor Spirit, thou deniest me this think but how thou shalt die (as I will work means for it ) no Murderer ever like thee; for I purpose to call this subtle sinful Snare of mine an Act of force from thee: thou art proud, and youthful I shall be believed; besides thy Wantonness is at this hour in question amongst our Women, Which will make ill for thee.
I had hard Chance to light upon this pleasure, that is so costly: and give him breath, but seeks to have that too.
well: take thy choice.
I see no Choice in it (Madam) for it is all death methinks

thou hast an ill sight then, of a young man, it is death if thou refuse it and say my zeal has warned thee: But consenting it will be new life, great Honour, and my Love, which in perpetual Bands, I will fasten to thee.
how Madam?
I will do it religiously. make thee my Husband: may I loose all sense of pleasure in life else: and be more miserable than ever Creature was: for nothing lives but has a Joy in some-what.
then by all the hopeful fortunes of a young man's Rising I will perform it (Madam)

there is a pledge then of a Duchess Love for thee: and now trust me for thy most happy safety: I will choose that Time, shall never hurt thee: when a Man shows Resolution, and there is worth in him I will have a Care of him: part now for this time but still be near about us, till thou canst be nearer, that is ourself.
and that I will venture hard for.
good speed to thee.
Prithee be careful of me, very careful now,
I warrant you : He that cannot be careful of a Quean, can be careful of nobody : it is every man's humour that: I should never look to a Wife half so handsomely.
o softly, (sweet Sir) should your Mistress meet me now in her own House, I were undone forever.
never fear her; She is at her Prick-song close, there is all the joy she has, or takes delight in look here is the Garden key, my Master gave it me, and willed me to be careful: doubt not you of it .
your Master is a noble Complete Gentleman, and does a woman all the right that may be.
how now? what is she?

I know that face to be a Strumpets; or mine eye is envious and would fain wish it so , where I would have it. I fail, if the Condition of this fellow wears not about it, a strong scent of Baseness, I saw her once before here, five days since, it is
and the same wary Pandarous diligence was then bestowed on her; She came altered then, and more inclining to the City-tuck. Whom should this Piece of Transformation visit after the common courtesy of frailty in our House here? surely not any Servant they are not kept so lusty, She so low; I am at a strange Stand, Love, and Luck assist me. the Truth I shall win from him, by false play he is now returned: Well Sir, as you were saying go forward with your Tale.
what? I know nothing.
the Gentlewoman
She is gone out at Backdoor now.
then farewell She, and you, if that be all
Come: Come, thou shalt have more: I have no power to lock myself up from thee.
so methinks.
you shall not think; trust me Sir, you shall not your ear: She is one of the falling famely a Quean, my Master keeps; she lies at Rutneys .
is it possible: I thought I had seen her some-where.

I tell you truth sincerely: She has been thrice here
by stealth within these ten days, and departed still with pleasure, and with thanks Sir, it is her luck, surely I think if ever there were man bewitched in this world it is my Master (Sirra)
thinkst thou so Gasper ?
o, Sir too apparent.
this may prove happy: it is the likeliest means that Fortune yet ever showed me.
you are both here now, and strangers newly lighted: where is your Attendance?

I know what makes you waspish: a pox on it
she will every day be angry now at nothing

I will call her stranger ever in my heart, She has killed the name of Sister, through base lust and fled to shifts: o, how a Brother's good thoughts may be be-guild in woman: Here is a Letter (found in her absence.) reports strangely of her and speaks her Impudence: she has undone herself. I could not hold from weeping, when I read it; abused her Brother's house, and his good confidence: it was done not like herself: I blame her much: but if She can but keep it from his knowledge
I will not grieve him first. it shall not Come by my means to his heart: Now Sir, the News?
You called them Strangers: it is my Masters Sister (Madam)
o , is it so : She is welcome: Who is come with her?
I see none but Abberzanes.

he is enough to bring a Woman to Confusion more than a wiser man, or a far greater. A letter came last week to her Brother's hands to make way for her Coming up again, after her shame was lightened; and she writ there the Gentleman her Mother wished her to (taking a Violent Surfeit, at a Wedding) died ere she came to see him: What strange Cunning Sin helps a woman to: here she comes now Sister, you are welcome home again.
thanks (sweet Sister)
you have had good speed.
what says she? I have made all the best speed, I could.
I well believe You.

my Service ever (Madam) to a Gentlewoman,
I took a bonny Mare I keep, and met her some ten mile out of town: eleven, I think. it was at the Stump I met you, I remember. at bottom of the Hill.
it was thereabout Sir.
full eleven then, by the rod, if they were measured
you look ill ( methinks) have you been sick of late? 'stroth, very bleak, doth she not? how think you Sir?
no: no: a little sharp with riding, she has rid sore.
I ever look lean after a Journey Sister one shall do, that has travelled: travelled hard.
till Evening, I commend you to yourselves, Ladies
and that is best trusting to, if you were hanged. you are well acquainted with his hand, went out now?
his hand?

I speak of nothing else: I think it is there. please you to look upon it: and when you have done if you did weep, it could not be amiss a sign you could say Grace, after a full Meal. You had not need look paler; Yet you do: it was ill done to abuse yourself, and us, to wrong so good a Brother, and the thoughts that we both held of you: I did doubt you much
before our marriage-day: but then my strangeness, and better hope still, kept me off, from speaking. yet may you find a kind, and peaceful Sister of me, if you desist here, and shake hands with folly, which you have more cause to do , than I to wish you; as truly as I bear a Love to Goodness, your Brother knows not yet of it , nor shall ever for my part, so you leave his Company: but if I find you impudent, in sinning I will not keep it an hour; nay, prove your Enemy and you know who will aid me: as you have goodness, You may make use of this; I will leave it with you .

here is a sweet Churching, after a Woman's Labour, and a five give you joy: why where the Devil lay you to be found out? the sudden hurry of hastening to prevent shame, brought shame forth. that is still the Curse of all lascivious Stuff Misdeeds could never yet be wary enough. Now must I stand in fear of every look: nay tremble at a Whisper: She can keep it secret? that is very likely, and a Woman too? I am sure I could not do it: and I am made as well as she can be for any purpose, it would never stay with me two days; I have cast it
the third would be a terrible sick day with me, not possible to bear it: should I then trust to her strength in it , that lies every night whispering the days news in a Husbands ear? No : and I have thought upon the means: blessed fortune; I must be quit with her, in the same fashion, or else it is nothing; there is no way like it, To bring her Honesty into question cunningly: My Brother will believe small likelihoods, coming from Me too ; I lying now in the house, may work things to my will, beyond Conceit too: Disgrace her first: her Tale will never be heard, I learned that Council first of a sound Guard. I do suspect Gasper , my Brother's Squire there had some hand in this mischief, For he is Cunning and I perhaps may fit him.
Your Sister told me you were come: thou art welcome.
where is she?
who? my wife?
Aye Sir.
within.
not within hearing, think you ?
Within hearing? What is thy conceit in that? why shakest thy head so ? and lookest so pale, and poorly?
I am a fool indeed to take such grief for others: for your fortune Sir,
my Fortune? worse things yet? farewell life then.

I fear
you are much deceived (Sir) in this Woman,
who? in my Wife? speak low: Come hither, softly Sister.
I love her as a Woman You made choice of, but when she wrongs you, Natural Love is touched (Brother) and that will speak you know.
I trust it will.
I held a shrewd suspicion of her Lightness at first, when I went down; Which made me haste the sooner but more, to make amends, at my Return now I found apparent signs.
apparent sayst thou?
Aye, and of base Lust too; that makes the affliction
there has been villainy wrought upon me then, it is too plain now.

happy are they, I say still that have their Sisters living in the House with them, their Mothers, or some Kindred: a great Comfort,
to all poor Married Men; it is not possible a young Wife can abuse a Husband then, it is found straight. but swear secrecy to this (Brother)
to this, and all thou wilt have.
then this follows, Sir
I praise thy Council well: I will put it in use straight See where she comes herself: Kind honest Lady, I must now borrow a whole fortnights leave of thee
how Sir? a fortnights?
It may be but ten days; I know not yet. it is Busyness for the State, and it must be done
I wish good speed to it then.
why that was well spoke, I will take but a footboy: I need no more. the rest I will leave at home, to do you service.
use your own pleasure, Sir.
till my Return you will be good Company: My Sister, and you
we shall make shift Sir,
I am glad now she is Come, and so the wishes of my love to both.
and our good prayers with you Sir.
Now my fortune. by your kind favour (Madam)
with me, Sir?
the words shall not be many: but the faithfulness and true respect, that is included in them, is worthy your Attention; and may put upon Me the fair repute of a just honest Servant.
What is here to do Sir, there is such great preparation toward?
in brief, that Goodness in you, is abused, Madam; you have the Married life, but it is a Strumpet that has the Joy of it, and the fruitfulness, there goes away your Comfort.
how? a Strumpet?
of five years cost, and upwards: a dear mischief (as they are all of them) his fortnights Journey is to that Country, if it be not rudeness to speak the truth, I have found it all out (Madam)
thou hast found out thine own Ruin: for to my knowledge thou dost be-lie him basely: I dare swear he is a Gentleman, as free from that folly as ever took religious life upon him.

be not too confident to your own Abuse (Madam) Since I have begun the truth, neither your frowns
the only Curses that I have on Earth (because my Means depends upon your Service) Nor all the execration of Man's Fury shall putt me off: though I be poor, I am honest, and too just in this Busyness: I perceive now, too much Respect, and faithfulness to Ladies may be a wrong to Servants .
art thou yet so impudent to stand in it?
are you yet so cold, (Madam,) in the belief of it ? there my wonder is fixed, having such blessed health, and youth about you, Which makes the Injury mighty

Why I tell thee it were too great a fortune for thy Lowness to find out such a thing: thou dost not look as if thou art made for it: by the precious Sweets of Love I would give half my Wealth, for such a Bargain and think it were bought too cheap: thou canst not guess thy Means; and happiness, should I find this true. first, I would prefer thee to the Lord, my Uncle, he is Governor of Rauenna, all the Advancements in the Kingdom, flows from him: What need I boast that. which Common fame can teach thee?

then thus (Madam) since I presume now on your height of Spirit and your regard to your own youth, and fruitfulness ( which every Woman naturally loves and covets) Accept but of my Labour, in directions, you shall both find your Wrongs ( which you may right at your own pleasure) yet not missed tonight here in the house neither: None shall take notice of any absence in you, as I have thought of it.
do this, and take my praise, and thanks forever .
as I deserve, I wish them: and will serve you
The Moon is a Gallant, see how brisk she rides
here is a rich Evening, Heccat.
Aye : is it not wenches, to take a Journey of five thousand Mile
ours will be more tonight
o , it will be precious: heard you the Owl yet?
briefly in the Copse, as we came through now:
it is high time for us then.

There was a Bat hung at my lips three times
as we came through the woods, and drank her fill. old Puckle saw her.
you are fortunate still the Very screech-owl lights upon Your shoulder and woos you, like a Pigeon: are you furnished? have you your Ointments?
all:
prepare to flight then I will over-take you swiftly
hie thee Heccat : We shall be up betimes
I will reach you quickly

they are all going a'Birding tonight : they talk of fowls in the Air, that fly by day, I am sure they will be a Company of fowl Sluts there tonight : if we have not Mortality after it, I will be hanged, for they are able to putrefy it; to Infect a whole Region: She spies me now.
what Fire-stone, our sweet Son?
a little sweeter than some of you ; or a Dunghill were too good for me.
how much hast here?
Nineteen , and all brave plump ones, besides six lizards, and three Serpentine Eggs.
dear, and sweet Boy; What herbs hast thou?
Marmaritin, and Mandragora, thou wouldst say. here is Pannax too: I thank thee
My Pan aches I am sure With kneeling down to Cut them .
and Selago, Hedge Hisop too: how near he goes my Cuttings? were they all cropped by Moonlight?
every Blade of them . or I am a moon calf (Mother)
hie thee home with them look well to the House tonight; I am for loft.
Aloft (quoth you?) I would you would break your neck once, that I might have all quickly: hark: hark Mother. they are above the Steeple already, flying over your head with a noise of Musicians
they are they indeed: help: help me: I am too late else.

l.emph: Come away: Come away:
Heccat: Heccat, Come away

lg.l: I come, I come, I come, I come,
with all the speed I may,

l.emph: with all the speed I may.
Here
where is Puckle

lg.l: here And Hoppo too, and Hellwaine too we lack but you; we lack but you, Come away, make up the count

l.emph: I will but noint, and then I mount.
There is one comes down to fetch his dues
a kiss, a Coll, a Sip of Blood
and why thou stayest so long
I muse, I muse.
Since the Air is so sweet, and good.

lg.l: o art thou come what news: what news?

All goes still to our delight , Either come, or else
Refuse: Refuse:
Now I am furnished for the Flight.

sp.p: hark, hark, the Cat sings a brave Treble in her own language.

lg.l:
Now I go , I fly, Malkin my sweet Spirit, and I. o what a dainty pleasure it is
to ride in the Air when the Moon shines fair
and sing, and dance, and toy, and kiss ; Over Woods, high Rocks, and Mountains , Over Seas, our Mistress Fountains , Over Steep Towers, and Turrets , we fly by night, amongst troops of Spirits , No Ring of Bells, to our Ears sounds
No howls of Wolves, no yelps of Hounds.
No, not the noise of waters-breach
or Cannons throat, our height can reach.

l.emph: No Ring of Bells to our Ears sounds
No howls of Wolves, no yelps of Hounds.
No, not the noise of waters-breach
or Cannons throat, our height can reach.

sp.p: Well Mother, I thank your kindness: You must be gambolling in the Air; and leave me to walk here, like a fool, and a Mortal.

Though the Fates have endued me with a pretty kind of Lightness, that I can laugh at the world in a Corner of it; and can make
myself merry on fasting-Nights to rub out a Supper (which were a precious Quality, in a young formal Studient, yet let the world know, there is some difference betwixt my Jovial Condition, and the Lunary state of Madness: I am not quite
out of my Wits: I know a Bawd, from an Aqua-vite shop, a Strumpet from Wildfire, and a Beadle from Brimstone. Now I shall try the honesty of a Great Woman soundly, She reckoning the Duke is made away, I will be hanged, if I be not the next now. If I trust her as She is a Woman, Let one of her long Hairs wind about my heart, and be the end of me, (which were a piteous Lamentable Tragedy, and might be entitled a fair Warning for all hair-Bracelets) Already there is an Insurrection among the People , they are up in Arms Not out of any reason, but their wills, (which are in them their Saints) sweating, and swearing (out of their Zeal to Rudeness ) that no Stranger (as they term her) shall govern over them, they say they will raise a Duke among themselves first
O Almachildes , I perceive already our Loves are born to Crosses: We are beset, by Multitudes: and (which is worse) I fear me Unfriended too of any: my chief Care is for thy sweet youths safety
He that believes you not goes the right way to heaven, on my conscience

there is no trusting of them : they are all as barren in Pity, as in Faith: he that putts confidence in them, dies openly to the sight of all men, not with his friends, and Neighbours, in peace private but as his shame, so his cold farewell is, public, and full of noise. But keep you close, Sir, not seen of any, till I see the way plain for your safety. I expect the Coming of the Lord Governor , Whom I will flatter
with fair Entreaties, to appease their wildness, and before him, take a great grief upon Me for the Dukes death; his strange and sudden loss and when a quiet comes, expect thy Joys
I do expect now to be made away say I have been careful, and shunned spoon-meat

This Fellow lives too long after the Deed, I am weary of his sight: he must die quickly, or I have small hope of Safety: My great Aim is
at the Lord Governor's love; he is a Spirit can sway, and Countenance: these obey and Crouch. My Guiltiness had need of such a Master, that with a beck can suppress Multitudes and dim Misdeeds, with radiance of his Glory. not to be seen with dazzled popular Eyes. and here behold him come.
Return back to them, say we desire them to be friends of Peace till they hear farther from us.

O my Lord. I fly unto the pity of your Nobleness, the grievest Lady, that was ever beset with storms of Sorrows, or wild rage of People. Never was Woman's grief for loss of Lord dearer than Mine, to Me.

there is no Right done
to Him now (Madam) by Wrong done to Yourself: your own good wisdom may instruct you so far: and for the Peoples Tumult (which oft grows from Liberty, or Rankness of long Peace) I will labour to restrain, as I have begun (Madam)
My thanks, and Prayers shall never forget you (Sir) and, in time to Come, my Love.

your Love (sweet Madam) You make my Joys too happy: I did covet to be the fortunate man, that Blessing visits Which I will esteem the Crown, and full Reward of Service present, and Deserts to come, It is a happiness I will be bold to sue for when I have set a Calm upon these Spirits that now are up for Ruin

Sir, my wishes are so well met in yours, so fairly answered and nobly recompensed, it makes me suffer in those extremes that few have ever felt, to hold two Passions, in one heart at once of Gladness, and of Sorrow.
then as the Olive is the meek Ensign of fair Fruitful Peace, so is this Kiss, of yours.
Loves power be with you, Sir.
how she has betrayed her; may I breathe no longer than to do Virtue service, and bring forth the fruits of Noble thoughts, honest, and Loyal. this will be worth the observing; and I will do it.

What a sure happiness confirms Joy to Me, now in the times of my most imminent dangers?, I looked for Ruin; and increase of Honour meets me auspiciously. But my hopes are clogged now with an unworthy weight: there is the misfortune, What course shall I take now with this young man, for he must be no hindrance: I have thought of it . I will take some Witches Council, for his End, that will be surest. (Mischief is Mischief's friend).
If ever you knew force of Love. in life Sir, give to mine pity
you do ill to doubt me.
I could make bold with no friend seemlier than with yourself. because you were in presence at our Vow-making
I am a Witness to it.

then you best understand, of all men living this is no wrong I offer, no abuse either to faith, or friendship: for we are registered Husband, and wife in heaven, though there wants that which often keeps licentious Man in awe from starting from their Wedlocks, the knot public, it is in our Souls knit fast, and how more precious the Soul is, than the Body, so much judge the sacred, and celestial Tie within us , more than the outward form, which calls but Witness here upon earth, to what is done in heaven. though I must needs confess, the least is honourable (as an Ambassador sent from a King has Honour by the Employment, yet there is greater dwells in the King that sent him; so in this)
I approve all you speak: and will appear to You a faithful pitying friend.

Look, there is She, Sir, One good for nothing but to make use of.
and I am constrained to employ her, to make all things plain, easy, and probable; For when She Comes and finds one here that Claims him, as I have taught both this to do it, and He, to Compound with her, it will stir belief the more of such a Busyness.
I praise the Carriage well.
hark you (sweet Mistress I shall do you a simple Turn in this: for She disgraced thus: you are up in favour forever, with her Husband.
that is my hope Sir, I would not take the pains else: have You the keys of the Garden-side, that I may get betimes in, closely, and take her Lodging?
yes, I have thought upon You, here be the keys.
marry, and thanks (sweet Sir) set me a'work so still.

your Joys are false ones: you are like to lie alone; you will be deceived of the Bedfellow you look for; else my purpose were in an ill case: he is on his fortnight's Journey you will find cold comfort there: a Dream will be
even the best Market you can make tonight : She will not be long now; You may loose no time neither: if She but take you at the door it is enough. When a Suspect doth Catch once, it burns mainly. there may you end your Busyness, and as cunningly as if you were in the Chamber; if you please, to use but the same Art.

What need you urge that, Which comes so naturally I cannot miss on it? What makes the Devil so greedy of a Soul but because he has lost his own; to all Joys lost: So it is our Trade to set Snares for other Women because we were once caught ourselves.

a sweet allusion: Hell, and a Whore it seems are Partners then, in one Ambition: yet thou art here deceived now thou canst set none to hurt, or wrong her Honour it rather makes it perfect: Best of friends that ever Loves extremities were blessed with I feel mine Arms with thee; and call my peace the Of-spring of thy friendship: I will think this night my wedding-night: and with a Joy as reverend, as Religion can make Man's I will embrace this Blessing: honest Actions
are Laws unto themselves, and that good fear which is on others forced, grows kindly there.
hark, hark: One knocks; away Sir: it is she certainly It sounds much like a woman's jealous Larum,
by your leave Sir
you are welcome Gentlewoman.
Our Ladyship, then stands us in no stead now One word in private Sir.~~
no surely for-sooth. there is no such here, you have mistook the House.
O Sir, that have I not: excuse me there I come not with such Ignorance: think not so Sir. it was told me at the entering of your House here by one that knows him too well.
who should that be?
nay Sir, betraying is not my profession: but here, I know he is: and I presume He would give me Admittance, if he knew of it. as one of his nearest friends.
you are not his Wife for-sooth?
yes, by my faith am I.
She goes here by the name of his Wife: good stuff But the bold Strumpet never told me that
We are so oft deceived that Let out Lodgings we know not whom to trust: it is such a world, there are so many odd tricks now a-days put upon House-keepers.
why? do you think I would wrong you, or the Reputation of your House? pray show me the way to him
he is asleep (Lady the Curtain is drawn about him.

well: well Sir, I will have that Care, I will not disease him much. Tread you but lightly: o, of what gross falsehood is Man's heart made of? had my first Love lived and returned safe, he would have been a light to all Men's Actions, his faith shined so bright

I cannot so deceive her it were too sinful, there is more Religion in my Love, than so : It is not treacherous Lust, that gives Content to an honest mind: and this could prove no better, Were it in Me, a part of manly Justice,
that have sought strange hard means to keep her Chaste to her first vow; and I to abuse her first. Better I never knew what Comfort were in Woman's love, than wickedly to know it. What could the falsehood of one Night avail him that must enjoy forever, or he is lost? it is the way rather to draw hate upon me: for (known) it is as impossible she should love me, as youth, in health, to dote upon a grief, or one that is robbed, and bound, to affect the Thief No, he that would Souls sacred Comfort win, must burn in pure love, like a Seraphin
Coelio ?
Sweet Madam.
thou hast deluded me: there is nobody .
how? I wonder he would miss (Madam) having appointed to, it were a strange Goodness if heaven should turn his heart now, by the way.
O , never Celio .

yes, I have known the like Man is not at his own disposing (Madam) the blessed Powers have provided better for him,
or he were miserable: he may come Yet it is early (Madam) if you would be pleased to embrace my Council, you should see this Night over. since you have bestowed this pains
I intend so.

that Strumpet would be found, else she should go
I curse the time now, I did ever make use of such a plague: Sin knows not what it does .

It is now my Brothers time: even much about it for though he dissembled a whole fortnights absence he comes again tonight: it was so agreed before he went: I must be-stir my Wits now to Catch this Sister of mine, and bring her name to some disgrace first, to preserve mine own: there is profit in that Cunning: She cast off my Company betimes tonight, by Tricks, and sleights, and I was well contented: I am resolved there is no hate lost between us: for I know she does not love me now, but painfully, like one that is forced to smile upon a grief
to bring some purpose forward: and I will pay her in her own Mettle. They are now all at rest, and Gasper there, and all: list: fast asleep he cries it hither: I must disease you straight Sir: For the maidservants, and the Girls of the house I spiced them lately with a drowsy Posset, they will not here in #hast: My Brother is Come, o , where is this key now for him? here it is happily: but I must wake him first: why Gasper: Gasper.
What a pox gasp you for?
Now I will throw it down.
who is that called me now? somebody called Gasper?
o , up , as thou art an honest fellow Gasper .
I shall not rise tonight then: what is the matter? Who is that? young Mistress?
Aye : up : up , Sweet Gasper . my Sister hath both knocked, and called this hour, and not a Maid will stir.
they will stir enough sometimes
hark: hark again: Gasper : o . run: run. prithee .
give me leave to cloth myself.

standest upon Clothing in an extremity? hark: hark again.
She may be dead ere thou comest: o in quickly He is gone: he cannot choose, but be took now or Met in his return; that will be enough Brother? here take this Light.
my careful Sister.
look first in his own Lodging, ere you enter,
o abused Confidence: here is nothing of him but what betrays him more.
then it is too true, Brother
I will make base Lust a terrible example, No Villainy ever paid dearer.
help: hold Sir,
I am deaf to all humanity
List: list: a strange and sudden silence after all, I trust he has spoiled them both: too dear a happiness. o how I tremble between doubts, and Joys

there perish both: down to the house of Falsehood Where perjurous Wedlock weeps: o perjurous woman she had took the Innocence of sleep upon her at my approach, and would not see me come, as if she had lain there, like a harmless soul and never dreamed of Mischief. What is all this now?
I feel no ease; the Burthen is not yet off so long as the Abuse sticks in my knowledge, o, it is a pain of hell, to know ones shame, had it been hid, and done, it had been done happy, for he that is Ignorant lives long, and merry.
I shall know all now: Brother
Come down quickly: for I must kill thee too.
Me?
stay not long if thou desirest to die with little pain Make haste I would wish thee, and come willingly if I be forced to come, I shall be cruel, above a Man to thee.
why Sir. my Brother?,
talk to thy soul, if thou wilt talk at all. to Me thou art lost forever.
this is fearful in you beyond all reason (Brother,) would you thus reward me for my Care and Truth shown to You?

a Curse upon them both: and Thee for Company, it is that too diligent thankless Care of thine makes me a Murderer, and that Ruins Truth
that lights me to the knowledge of my Shame. hadst thou been secret, then had I been happy and had a hope (like Man) of Joys to Come Now here I stand, a Stain to my Creation: and, which is heavier than all Torments to me the understanding of this base Adultery, and that, thou toldest me first, which thou deservest Death worthily for.
if that be the worst, hold Sir, hold Brother, I can ease your knowledge straight by my souls hopes I can: there is no such thing
how?
bless me but with life, I will tell you all. Your Bed was never wronged.
what? never wronged?

I ask but mercy, as I deal with Truth now, it was only my Deceit, my Plot, and Cunning to bring disgrace upon her, by that means to keep mine own hid, which none knew but she to speak troth I had a Child by Aberzanes, Sir
How? Aberszanes ?

and my Mothers Letter
Was counterfeited, to get time, and Place for my delivery.
O, my Wrath is redoubled,

At my Return, she could speak all my folly and blamed me, with good Council: I, for fear it should be made known, thus rewarded her, Wrought you into suspicion without cause: And at your Coming, raised up Gasper suddenly, sent him but in before you , by a falsehood, Which (to your kindled Jealousy) I knew would add enough: what is now confessed is true

the more I hear, the worse it fares with me. I have killed them now for nothing: yet the shame follows my Blood still:: Once more come down Look you, My Sword goes up: Call Hermio to me, Let the new Man alone: he will wake too soon to find his Mistress dead, and loose a Service; Already the day breaks upon my Guilt I must be brief, and sudden. Hermio
Sir

Run: knock
up Aberzanes speedily; say I desire his Company this Morning
to yonder horse-Race, tell him: That will fetch him, o , hark you , by the way ~~.
yes Sir.

Use speed now: Or I will never use thee more: and perhaps
I speak in a right hour: my grief overflows, I must in private go , and vent my Woes
You are Welcome Sir,
I think I am worthy of it For look you (Sir,) I come untrussed. (in troth)
the more is the pity: (honester Men go to it ) that Slaves should scape it: What Blade have you got there?
Nay, I know not that (Sir) I am not acquainted greatly with the Blade; I am sure it is a good Scabbard, and that satisfies me,
it is long enough indeed, if that be good.
I love to Wear a long Weapon: it is a thing commendable
I pray draw it, Sir
It is not to be drawn.
Not to be drawn?
I do not Care to see it : to tell you troth Sir, it is only a Holiday thing, to wear by a man's side
draw it, or I will rip thee down from Neck to Navel though there is small glory in it.
are you in earnest, Sir?
I will tell thee that anon.
why, what is the matter Sir?

What a base misery is this in life now. This Slave had so much daring Courage in him to Act a sin, would shame whole Generations, but hath not so much honest strength about him to draw a Sword, in way of Satisfaction, this shows thy great Guilt, that thou darest not fight
yes, I dare fight (Sir) in an honest Cause.
why come then (Slave) thou hast made my Sister a Whore.
prove that an honest Cause, and I will be hanged.

so many starting-holes? Can I light no way? go too, you shall have your wish: all honest play. Come forth thou fruitful Wickedness: thou seed
of Shame, and Murder, Take to thee in Wedlock Baseness, and Cowardice: a fit Match for thee. Come Sir, along with me
alas: What to do I am too young to take a wife, in troth.

but old enough to take a Strumpet, though: you would fain get all Your Children before-hand, and Marry, when you have done : that is a strange course Sir, This woman I bestow on thee: What dost thou say.
I would I had such another to bestow on You, Sir
Uncharitable Slave: Dog: Coward as thou art to wish a plague were so great as thine, to any.
to my friend Sir, where I think I may be bold
down; and do it solemnly: Contract yourselves. With truth, and zeal, or never rise up again: I will not have her die in the state of Strumpet though she took pride to live one: Hermio the Wine
it is here Sir: 'stroth, I wonder at some things, but I will keep honest.

So , here is to you both now. and to your Joys, if it be your luck to find them , I tell you , you must weep hard, if you do :
Divide it betwixt you both: you shall not need a strong Bill of Divorcement after that if you mislike your Bargain. Go, get in, now, Kneel, and pray heartily to get forgiveness of those two Souls, whose Bodies thou hast murdered. Spread subtle Poison. Now my Shame in her will die, when I die: there is some comfort yet I do but think how each man's punishment proves still a kind of Justice to himself I was the Man, that told this Innocent Gentlewoman (whom I did falsely wed, and falsely kill) That he that was her Husband first, by Contract was slain in the field; and he
is known yet to live. So did I cruelly beguile her heart for which I am well rewarded: so is Gasper who, to befriend my Love, swore fearful oaths, he saw the last Breath fly from him. I see now it is a thing dreadful to abuse holy Vows and falls most weighty
take Comfort Sir, You are guilty of no death: they are only hurt, and that not mortally
thou breathest untruths,
Speak Gasper, for me then.
Your unjust Rage, Sir has hurt me, without cause.
it is changed to Grief for it. how fares my wife.
No doubt Sir, She fares well. for She never felt your fury: The poor Sinner that hath this seven year, kept herself sound for you it is your luck to bring her into the Surgeons hands now.
Florida.
She; I know no other, Sir, You were never at charge yet, but with one Light horse
why where is your Lady? where is my wife tonight then
nay ask not me, Sir; your struck-Doa within tells a strange tale of her
this is unsufferable Never had man such means to make him mad. O, that the Poison, would but spare my life till I had found her out.

your wish is granted Sir, upon the faithfulness of a pitying Servant I gave you none at all; my heart was kinder, Let not Conceit abuse you, you are as healthful (for any drug,) as life yet ever found you.

why here is a happiness, wipes off mighty Sorrows the benefit of ever-pleasing Service bless thy profession. O my worthy Lord I have an ill Bargain: Never man had worse the Woman that (unworthy) wears your Blood to countenance Sin in her: your Niece; she is false,
false?
Impudent-adulterous.
you are too loud, and grow too bold too, with her Virtuous Meekness, who dare accuse her.
here is one dare and can: she lies this night with Celio , her own Servant , the Place Fernando's house.
thou dost amaze us.

why here is but Lust translated from one Baseness into another ; here I thought to have caught them , but lighted wrong, by false Intelligence and made me hurt the Innocent: But now I will make my Revenge dreadfuller than a Tempest, an Army should not stop me; or a Sea divide them from my Revenge.

I will not speak to have her spared, if she be base, and guilty. if otherwise, heaven will not see her wronged,
I need not take care for her: Let that Woman be carefully looked to, (both for health, and sureness,) it is not that mistaken wound, thou wearest shall be thy privilege
you cannot torture me worse than the Surgeon does: so long I care not. if she be adulterous I will never trust Virtues in Women, they are but Veils for lust.

to what a lasting Ruin, mischief Runs, I had thought I had well, and happily ended all in keeping back the poison, and new rage now spreads a worse venom; My poor Lady grieves me, it is strange to me, that her sweet seeming Virtues should be so meanly over-took, with Celio , a Servant, it is not possible.
good morrow Hermio my Sister stirring yet?
how? stirring forsooth: here has been simple stirring: Are you not hurt Madam: pray speak, we have a Surgeon ready.
how a Surgeon?
hath been at work these five hours.
how he talks.
did you not meet my Master .
how your Master ? why came he home tonight ?
then know you nothing. Madam please you but walk in, you shall hear strange business
I am much beholding to your Truth now, am I not? you have served me fair: my credit is stained forever
this is the wickedest fortune, that ever blew We are both undone, for nothing: there is no way flatters Recovery now; the Thing is so gross her disgrace grieves me more, than a lifes loss
What death is it you desire for Almachildes ?
a sudden, and a subtle.
then I have fitted you , here lie the Gifts of both, sudden, and subtle. his Picture made in wax, and gently molten by a blue fire, kindled with dead men's Eyes will waste him by degrees.
in what time, prithee?
perhaps in a Moons progress,
what? a Month? out upon pictures, if they be so tedious give me things with some life
then seek no farther.
this must be done with speed: dispatched this night. if it may be possible
I have it for you here is that will do it: stay but perfections time, and that is not five hours hence.
Canst thou do this
Can I?
I mean so closely.
so closely do you mean too?
so artfully: so cunningly

worse, and worse; doubts, and Incredulities they make me mad: Let scrupulous Greatness know Cum Volui ripis ipsis mirantibus Amnes, in Fontes rediere suos, concussaque sisto, Stantia Concutio, Cantu Freta Nubila Pello, Nubilaque induco, Ventos, Abigoque Vocoque, Viperias rumpo Verbis, et Carmine fauces, Et Siluas moueo, Iubeoque tremiscere Montes Et mugire Solum, Manes-que exire Sepulchris. Teque Luna traho. Can you doubt me then daughter? That can make Mountains tremble, Miles of woods walk Whole Earths foundation bellow, and the Spirits
of the entombed, to burst out from their Marbles; nay, draw yond Moon, to my involved Designs
I know as well as can be, when my Mother is mad and our great Cat angry; for one spits french then, and the other spits Latin.
I did not doubt you , Mother.
No? what did you My Power is so firm, it is not to be questioned.
forgive what is past: and now I know the offensiveness that vexes Art, I will shun the occasion ever.

Leave all to me, and my five Sisters, Daughter. It shall be conveyed in at Howlott-time take you no Care; My Spirits know their Moments, Raven, or Screech-owl never fly by the door but they call in (I thank them;) and they loose not by it I give them Barley, soaked in Infants Blood they shall have Semina, cum Sanguine their gorge crammed full, if they come once to our house. We are no Niggard.
they fare but too well when they come hither: they eat up as much the other night, as would have made me a good conscionable Pudding

give me some Lizards
Brain: quickly Firestone where is Grannam Stadlin, and all the rest of the Sisters?
all at hand forsooth.
give me Mar maritin: some Bear breech: when.
here is Bear breech , and Lizards brain forsooth.
Into the Vessel; and fetch three ounces of the red-haired Girl I killed last midnight.
whereabouts, sweet Mother?
Hip: Hip, or flank: where is the Acopus?
you shall have Acopus . forsooth.
stir: stir about: whilst I begin the Charm.

lg.l:
Black Spirits, and white: Red Spirits, and Gray , Mingle, Mingle, Mingle, you that mingle may.
Titty, Tiffin: keep it stiff in
Fire-Drake, Puckey, Make it Luckey.
Liand, Robin, you must bob in
Round, around, around, about, about
All ill come running in, all Good keep out.

l.emph: here is the Blood of a Bat.

lg.l: Put in that: o put in that .

l.emph: here is Libbards Bane
Put in again
the Juice of Toad: the Oil of Adder
those will make the younker madder.

lg.l: Put in: there is all. and rid the Stench .
nay here is three ounces of the red-haired wench. all Round: around: around etc:.

sp.p: so: so enough: into the Vessel with it there it hath the true perfection: I am so light at any mischief; there is no Villainy but is a Tune methinks
A Tune: it is to the Tune of damnation then: I warrant you: and that Song hath a villainous Burthen.
Come my sweet Sisters: let the Air strike our Tune whilst we show Reverence to yond peeping Moon.

My Lord, I have given you nothing but the truth of a most plain, and Innocent intent, My wrongs being so apparent, in this Woman (a Creature that robs Wedlock of all Comfort,
Wherever she fastens) I could do no less but seek means privately to shame his folly: No farther reached my Mallice, and it glads me that none but my base Injurer is found to be my false Accuser.

this is strange that he should give the wrongs, yet seek Revenge. first by your Lady, for a false Intelligence that caused her Absence, which much hurts her Name, though her Intents were blameless: Next by this woman for an Adulterous design, and Plot practiced between you to entrap her Honour, whilst she, for hire, should enjoy her Husband. Your Answer
part of this is truth (my Lord) to which I am guilty, in a rash Intent, but clear in Act; and She most clear in both; not sanctity more spotless.
o my Lord
what news breaks there?
of strange destruction: Here stands the Lady, that within this hour was made a Widow.

how?
Your Niece , (my Lord.) a fearful unexpected Accident brought death, to meet his fury: for my Lord entering Fernando's house, like a raised Tempest (which nothing heeds but its own violent rage) blinded with Wrath, and Jealousy, (Which scorn guides) from a false Trapdoor, fell into a Depth exceeds a Temples height: Which takes into it part of the dungeon, that falls threescore Fathom under the Castle.
o you Seed of Lust Wrongs, and Revenges wrongful, with what Terrors you do present yourselves to Wretched man, when his soul least expects you?
I forgive him all his wrongs now, and sign it with my pity
o my sweet Servant.
look to yond light Mistress
she is in a Swoon (my Lord)
Convey her hence, It is a sight would grieve a modest eye to see a Strumpets soul sink into Passion, for him that was the Husband of another : yet all this clears not you?
thanks to heaven that I am now of age to clear myself then.
Sebastian?
the same, much wronged: (Sir)
am I certain of what mine eye takes joy to look upon?
your service cannot alter me from knowledge. I am your Servant ever.
welcome to life (Sir) Gasper, thou sworest his death.
I did indeed (my Lord) and have been since well paid for it : one for-sworn mouth hath got me two, or three more here.

I was dead (Sir) both to my Joys, and all men's understanding till this my hour of life: for it was my fortune to make the first of my Return to Vrbin a witness to that Marriage: since which time I have walked beneath myself, and all my Comforts, like one on Earth, whose Joys are laid above. and though it had been offence small in me to enjoy my own, I left her pure, and free.

the greater, and more sacred is thy Blessing, for where Heavens Bounty, holly ground-work finds
it is like a Sea, encompassing chaste Minds
The Duchess Comes my Lord.
be you then all Witnesses of an Intent most horrid

one poor night ever Almachildes now: better his meaner fortunes wept than ours , that took the true height of a Princess Spirit to Match unto their Greatness: such lifes as his were only made to break the force of fate ere it came at us , and receive the Venom. it is but a usual friendship for a Mistress
to loose some forty years life, in hopeful time and hazard an eternal soul forever . as young as he has done , and more desert-full.
Madam.
my Lord.
this is the hour, that I have so long desired the Tumult is full appeased: Now may we both exchange Embraces, with a fortunate Arm and practise to make love-knots, thus.
my Lord?

thus lustful Woman and bold Murderess thus. Blessed Powers, to make my loyalty, and Truth so happy Look thee, thou shame of Greatness: Stain of Honour, behold thy work, and weep before thy death if thou beest blessed with sorrow, and a Conscience
Which is a Gift from heaven, and seldom knocks at any Murderers breast, with sounds of Comfort See, this thy Worthy, and unequalled Piece a fair encouragement for another Husband.

bestow me upon death Sir, I am guilty and of a Cruelty above my Cause, his Injury was too low, for my Revenge performs a Justice, that may light all others to Noble Actions: life is hateful to me, beholding my dead Lord; Make us an one in death, whom Marriage made one, of two Living. till cursed fury parted us; My Lord I covet to be like him.

No, my Sword shall never stain the virgin brightness of it
with blood of an Adulteress.
there my Lord, I dare my Accuser, and defy the world Death, shame, and Torment, Blood, I am guilty of but not Adultery: not the breach of Honour.
No: Come forth Almachildes
Almachildes? hath Time brought him about to save himself by my destruction? I am justly doomed
do you know this Woman?
I have known her better Sir, than at this time
but she defies you there.
that is the common trick of them all.
Nay since I am touched so near: before my death then In right of Honours Innocence, I am bold to call heaven, and my Woman here to Witness. My Lord, let her speak truth, or may she perish.

Then Sir, by all the hopes of a Maids Comfort either in faithful service, or blessed Marriage the Woman that his blinded folly knew was only a hired Strumpet: a Professor of Lust, and Impudence: Which here is ready
A common Strumpet? this Comes of Scarves; I will never more wear an Haberdashers shop before mine eyes again.
my Sword is proud, thou art lightened of that sin, die then a Murderess only:
live a Duchess better than ever loud; embraced, and honoured.
my Lord?

Nay, since in honour thou canst justly rise vanish all wrongs: thy former Practise dies I thank thee Almachildes for my life this Lord, for Truth, and Heaven for such a Wife, Who, though her Intent sinned, yet she makes amends
With Grief, and Honour. (Virtues noblest Ends) What grieved you then, shall never more offend you, Your Father's Skull, with honour we will Inter and give the Peace, due to the Sepulchre ; And in all Times, may this day ever prove
a day of Triumph, Joy, and honest Love
